title: How to Remove Stains from Tea Cups Using Baking Soda

steps.title: Wash the cup as usual.
steps.content: Wash the cup as usual. This will get rid of any extra gunk that can be taken off with regular soapy water. [1] X Expert Source Jon Gholian Cleaning Specialist Expert Interview. 15 December 2020. Start with cups that are as clean as possible. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Dampen the cup.
steps.content: Dampen the cup. If your cup isn't already wet, dampen it with some hot water. It's easier to remove the stain when there is little moisture present for the baking soda to cling to.

steps.title: Sprinkle baking soda into the cup.
steps.content: Sprinkle baking soda into the cup. Half a teaspoon or so should do the trick. You only need enough to make a light paste.

steps.title: Rub the stain with a soft cloth.
steps.content: Rub the stain with a soft cloth. You can use a soft microfiber cloth. [3] X Expert Source Jon Gholian Cleaning Specialist Expert Interview. 15 December 2020. A paste-like film should form as you rub over the dampened cup. Concentrate on places where the stain is darkest.

steps.title: Check the stain and continue rubbing.
steps.content: Check the stain and continue rubbing. Put some effort into rubbing directly over the stained areas of the cup. Continue doing this until the stain lifts. You may need to turn the cup around as you are scrubbing, to ensure that you reach all areas of the stain.

steps.title: Rinse out the cup.
steps.content: Rinse out the cup. Remove the baking soda residue from the cup with warm water. [4] X Expert Source Jon Gholian Cleaning Specialist Expert Interview. 15 December 2020. Check that you have removed the entire stain. If it's gone, turn the cup upside down and leave to air dry before returning to its usual storage spot.

steps.title: Repeat if necessary.
steps.content: Repeat if necessary. If you still see remnants of the stain after a good scrubbing, repeat the process with more baking soda. It will usually come off after an extra treatment or two.
